resources.title: You’re a credit to your race.***
resources.definition:
This comment implies that it is not the norm for a person of a particular race or ethnicity to be intelligent or respectable.

It makes assumptions about behaviour expected from a race/ethnic group. It’s rooted in stereotypes. The person who’s making the comment often sees it as a compliment. However, it suggests that whiteness signifies intelligence and integrity. It can communicate to the person on the receiving end of this comment that they're seen as an exception.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: You're so [[articulate]]!
resources.definition: This comment is usually directed at racialized individuals, immigrants, people who do not speak English as their mother tongue, and people with disabilities. It is sometimes also directed at young people. It is often meant as a compliment or is meant to be well-intended, however, it often conceals our biases and expectations of the capabilities of people of certain identities and backgrounds. Negative expectations related to capability are based on stereotypes and biases. These statements can cause people to doubt themselves, make them lose confidence in their abilities, and ultimately uphold societal stereotypes related to professionalism.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: ((Confusing)) ((racialized)) coworkers for each other.
resources.definition: This behaviour perpetuates the notion that all people of a particular racialized group look and act the same. It suggests that they cannot be differentiated. It can make people feel invisible and unimportant. It can also make someone feel as though they're not valuable enough to be remembered.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Calling women [[crazy,]] [[bitchy,]] and/or [[hysterical]].
resources.definition:
These comments communicate that women are too emotional and unstable. They suggest that women can’t be taken seriously. 

Women often receive these comments when expressing an opinion or setting boundaries. These stereotypes reinforce the belief that women are irrational. They devalue womens’ opinions. They can also hinder their success (i.e., jobs, relationships, etc.). This is a form of gaslighting. It can have a negative impact on mental health.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: You’re X years ((young)).
resources.definition: This statement may seem like a compliment, but it has a relationship to everyday ageism. It is connected to attitudes that value and glorify youth in certain contexts. This can suggest that being older is shameful and/or embarrassing. This statement holds underlying negative feelings about aging.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: You’re such an [[old]] [[man]].
resources.definition:
This statement suggests that older people may be a burden to others and are not valuable members of society.

It may cause older people and their skills to be diminished or overlooked, as well as labelled “out of date” or “behind the times”. That affects how those labelled as “old” see themselves, as they are being told they are irrelevant. That can lead them to second-guess their own abilities and worth. It also signals to others that aging is something to be feared or a sign of weakness.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: [[Misgendering]] someone or using [[incorrect]] [[pronouns]].
resources.definition:
This behaviour invalidates a person’s identity. When done on purpose, it’s harassment. 

It can create a feeling of discomfort. It implies you don’t respect someone’s identity. This behaviour is usually based on gender stereotypes, expectations and gender binaries.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Wow, you speak [[English]] [[so]] [[well]].
resources.definition:
This comment is often intended to be a compliment, however it stems from stereptype/perception that racialized people’s first language is not English and/or that they would not speak English well. Comments like this often go hand-in-hand with other similar comments like “where are you really from”.

Comments like these can cause a racialized person to feel like they don’t belong or that they are an outsider.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Crossing the street [[to]] [[avoid]] a [[racialized]] [[person]].
resources.definition: This behaviour is rooted in stereotypes. It can signal to others that they’re seen as dangerous or a criminal. These stereotypes frame racialized people as aggressive and threatening. This fear can lead to an increase in police violence against them.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Mistaking a racialized person for a service worker.***
resources.definition: This action is based on stereotypes that automatically link racialized people to service worker jobs. It is based on the bias that racialized people are less educated and lower skilled, and perpetuates the idea that success is synonymous with whiteness. It also perpetuates the belief that success cannot be linked to a service worker role, and views those that work in these jobs as less than others.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Correcting someone’s grammar to belittle or shame them.***
resources.definition: This behaviour is a form of shaming. It is usually English language based. In some cases, it may be helpful to assist with one’s grammar, however it can become a microaggression when done in an effort to shame someone and insult their intelligence, experiences, and self-esteem. It is commonly seen on social media where one individual comments on someone’s grammar to make people view them as uneducated or to discredit the actual content behind a person's words. It reinforces perceptions linked to education, speech, and intelligence/qualification. It can make the person speaking feel ashamed and not confident to speak up anymore. This microaggression may be used to slight or belittle one’s speech, dialect, and ultimately uphold Western, English ways of speaking.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: How can you not want children?***
resources.definition:
This comment is most often directed at women and rooted in belief that all women should become mothers.

It suggests that there’s something wrong with being childfree. It can also signal to women that they are selfish or can't live fulfilling lives without kids. It assumes that there are no physical, financial or other barriers to having or raising kids. This can cause anxiety in younger women who might feel like they’re doing something wrong. It can also cause shame in older women who’ve chosen to not bear children or cannot have children for a variety of reasons.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Ascription of Intelligence***
resources.definition: The act of assuming intelligence based on race. This can manifest in thinking that certain racialized groups are not as smart as others, for example. This perpetuates stereotypes and biases.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Elderspeak***
resources.definition: A way of speaking to older people and people with disabilities. It involves the use of exaggerated and simple vocabulary, slowing down speech, using pet names like “sweetie”, and others. It stems from negative stereotypes about capacity and can be infantilizing and condescending.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: __Unnecessary__ __focus__ on gender / sexuality by doctor.
resources.definition:
This type of focused conversation by health providers can be very harmful. If a 2SLGBTQ+ patient is coming in to discuss their mental or physical health, the conversation should not shift to body modification, genitalia, sexual orientation, gender identity, etc.

When a doctor or health provider does this, it can make the patient feel uncomfortable and called out. It sends the message that their doctor views them differently or as “abnormal”. This can cause a person to lose trust in their provider. They may stop seeking help if they believe health providers don’t have their best interest at heart.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Why aren’t you __married__ __yet__?
resources.definition:
This type of question assumes that marriage should be a person’s goal and can invalidate relationships they may have. While women seem to get this comment the most from strangers and friends and family alike, it's experienced by people of all genders.

Questions like these put pressure on the person and suggest that something is wrong with them for not being married. It can trivialize their life choices and attempts to make them conform to societal expectations of how they should lead their life.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: You’ll have to fight the boys off with a stick.***
resources.definition: This phrase is most often said to dads of daughters. It’s saying that their daughter is so pretty that boys won’t be able to control themselves around her, and that her dad will have to be the one to protect her from them. This phrase is offensive to both boys and girls. It suggests that boys are incapable of treating girls with respect (and works in tandem with other microaggressions like “boys will be boys’). It also suggests that girls won’t be able to advocate for themselves and will need the male parent to come to her rescue.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Falling on [[deaf]] [[ears]].
resources.definition:
These sayings are a form of ableist language. They use disability as a way to describe something negative or inferior. It relates being deaf with someone choosing to stay ignorant. This type of comment reinforces negative attitudes towards people with disabilities.

It’s similar to the saying, “turn a blind eye”.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Turn a [[blind]] [[eye]].
resources.definition:
These sayings are a form of ableist language and use disability as a way to describe something negative or inferior. It relates being blind with someone choosing to stay ignorant. This type of comment reinforces negative attitudes towards people with disabilities. It says that being blind is bad, wrong or problematic.

It’s similar to the saying, “falling on deaf ears”.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Calling something or someone __tone__ __deaf__.
resources.definition: These sayings are a form of ableist language. They use disability as a way to describe something negative or inferior. It relates being deaf with someone who is out of touch or insensitive. This type of comment sustains negative attitudes towards people with disabilities. It says that being deaf is bad, wrong or problematic.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Assuming someone is poor [[because]] [[they’re]] [[lazy.]]
resources.definition: This behaviour fails to recognize the difficulties of living in poverty and systemic barriers that exist. It implies that everyone has the same opportunities for economic empowerment and wealth. It accuses people of being too lazy and/or unmotivated to strive for economic empowerment. It fails to recognize barriers (including systemic barriers) that cause poverty. It can make someone feel judged. It can also prevent them from seeking help. It can perpetuate stereotypes and further prevent individuals from obtaining employment.
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: It’s great that you don’t drink.***
resources.definition: This comment perpetuates stereotypes related to Indigenous Peoples and the consumption of alchohol. This stereotype is harmful and perpetuates barriers in Indigenous Peoples’ lives (at work, when accessing leadership roles, etc.)
resources.author: Micropedia_Team

resources.title: Asking a woman who isn’t wearing makeup if she’s tired.***
resources.definition: This question normalises gendered norms, stereotypes, and standards particularly related to appearance. It suggests that women need makeup to appear healthy and acceptable, and further reinforces standards of beauty that women must adhere to in order to be accepted, to be taken seriously, etc.
resources.author: idv

resources.title: Referring to the work of [[fathers]] [[as]] [[babysitting]].
resources.definition: Using the term “babysitting” to refer to the actions of fathers reduces their role as a parent and implies that they are the secondary parent in a heterosexual relationship. It also reinforces gender roles and stereotypes that expect women to be the primary parent. Further, gendered expectations that place domestic and child care as the sole or primary responsibility of women and mothers are often related to discrimination in the labour market.
resources.author: lindseyehman

resources.title: You don’t look like you have a disability.***
resources.definition: This comment implies that only disabilities that can be seen are valid. It diminishes the feelings of someone whose disability cannot be visually seen and implies that there is a universal notion of what it means to be a person with a disability and what a person with a disability looks like/how they should act, thus reinforcing stereotypes, expectations, and perceptions. This also has implications on resource delivery - if resources support only those with visible disabilities, this may perpetuate a lack of support for those with invisible and episodic disabilities.
resources.author: tbielert

resources.title: Telling someone they will be promoted __due__ __to__ __their__ __race/gender__.
resources.definition: This comment diminishes a person’s work performance and achievement. It implies the person would only get promoted because of their identity, instead of their talent. It reduces the organisation’s diversity goals to performative actions rather than a culture of belonging and equity. It reinforces messaging that promoting white, cis-gendered people is the norm, and implies that these people will now “lose” out on opportunities due to the organization’s diversity targets.
resources.author: rosie

resources.title: Your husband already works! You don’t need this job!***
resources.definition: This statement reinforces gender roles related to work life and home responsibilities. It reproduces the belief that women ought to stay home and carry out domestic work while men ought to be working outside of the home. It can be used as a justification for paying women less and/or not offering women work opportunities by implying that her work would be supplemental to her husband’s.
resources.author: rebeccakane

resources.title:
Believing a bisexual/ 
pansexual marriage means they’ve picked a side.***
resources.definition: This comment assumes both a gender and sexual binary and diminishes the relationships of those of who are bisexual, pansexual, or another sexual identity. Assuming that bisexual and pansexual people have “picked a side” is part of the larger issue of bisexual/pansexual erasure or invisibility. Bisexual and pansexual erasure is when the existence and/or the legitimacy of bisexuality and pansexuality is questioned, trivialized, or denied.
resources.author: rebeccakane

resources.title: Whitesplaining***
resources.definition: This act is when white people explain racism to racialized people. This can range from white people telling racialized people that their experiences of racism are invalid, to them trying to “educate” Black/racialized people about racism. For example, a white person telling a Black person what language is appropriate to describe the Black person’s own race, or telling them if and when they should be offended, etc. Whitesplaining is similar to mansplaining in some aspects.
resources.author: ejwright

resources.title: Asking a transgender person to give you a Transgender 101.***
resources.definition: This request puts the onus on the transgender individual. Asking them to explain to you “all things transgender”, asking loads of questions, etc. is putting more burden on the individual to educate you, rather than you making an effort to educate yourself. It’s important for individuals to research issues themselves, and for them to take the initiative to learn before asking someone to do all the work on your learning. It also implies that there is a manual to understanding one’s identity, however people and experiences are unique, and what may apply to one individual may not apply to another.
resources.author: justbconsulting

resources.title: You have too many Gods.***
resources.definition: This statement minimizes and invalidates the views of people who practice Hinduism without truly understanding them. It is rooted in ignorance where faiths such as Christianity are deemed to be favoured, and implies that there is a “correct” format for religion. It also furthers the misinformation and misunderstanding of Hinduism, and stereotypes that are commonly held about Hinduism.

resources.title: You don't look like [gender/ race/ ethnicity/ age/ religion/ etc].***
resources.definition: This comment can be applied to people of different gender identities, members of the 2SLGBTQ+ community, people of different religions, races, ethnicities, ages, abilities, and others. It implies that a person falls outside of our (often stereotypical) perceptions and expectations of them as part of a particular group or community. This comment diminishes an individual’s identity and their belonging to groups or communities, and perpetuates stereotypes linked to the group or community as a whole.

resources.title: What are you anyway?***
resources.definition: This comment assumes that a person must identify as only one part of their ancestry, ethnicity, culture, gender, etc. and attempts to dictate the way people experience forms of their identity. It assumes that people who do not fit neatly into defined categories are  abnormal. It privileges some identities above others and perpetuates harmful stereotypes. It discourages people from being their whole selves and can erode self-acceptance and self-worth as well as acceptance by others. An example of this is when it’s asked of a mixed-race individual.

resources.title: Infantilization***
resources.definition: This behaviour involves talking down to others or treating adults like they are children or infants. It makes the assumption that people lack competency, agency, intelligence, experience, education, understanding etc. to manage on their own. It perpetuates harmful stereotypes and denies full personhood. It is the behaviours and ways of speaking often used when engaging with people with disabilities, individuals whose first language is not English, women, and others.

resources.title: People having a conversation and __intentionally__ __excluding__ __one__ __person__.
resources.definition: This behaviour promotes invisibility and sends the message that the person doesn’t matter or is of a lesser value. This can be aimed at women, people with disabilities, racialized people, young people, older people, and others depending on the context and signals that a person is not welcome in the discussion and their opinion isn’t valuable.
resources.author: kate

resources.title: He’s just __a__ __little__ __too__ __gay__.
resources.definition: This comment polices the behaviours of people in the 2SLGBTQ+ community. People who are part of the 2SLGBTQ+ community are often told to “tone down” their personality to make others more comfortable. This comment implies there are certain personality characteristics associated with being gay, and that these require “toning down”, thus perpetuating stereotypes and expectations.
resources.author: lola

resources.title: Asking someone to change their appearance to [[look]] [[more]] [[like]] [[an]] [[executive]].
resources.definition: This comment reinforces an expectation that women need to present a certain way to be authoritative. It de-emphasizes a woman’s talents and perspectives and instead focuses on gender stereotypes and expectations related to how women dress, act, and present themselves, and how they are expected to dress and act to be taken seriously. This is also often rooted in norms related to masculinity and femininity. This comment may also be directed at racialized people and people of different religions. It may take the form of asking someone to change their hair, their style of dress, removing religious symbols, or others. It assumes that there is one ideal identity that is a symbol of professionalism. This impacts a person’s self-perception, while also perpetuating societal stereotypes.
resources.author: alyp888

resources.title: Oh, you were born in Canada?***
resources.definition: This question has an underlying assumption that racialized individuals are not born in Canada and must have immigrated here. It enforces the idea that whiteness is synonymous with being Canadian and anyone who is not while is an “outsider”.
resources.author: aman

resources.title: You sure you can lift that?***
resources.definition: This question is often directed at women and implies they are weak and cannot perform certain tasks that men can do. It is based on gender stereotypes related to masculinity and femininity and serves to further perpetuate stereotypes and expectations.
resources.author: kaylacassar04

resources.title: I am not attracted to “X” race.***
resources.definition: This comment is most often directed to racialized individuals. Saying you are not attracted to a specific racialized group may be rooted in dominant beauty standards and stereotypes linking beauty to whiteness. Often, racist stereotypes toward specific groups in turn inform racial “preferences”. Saying you are not attracted to an entire race implies that all individuals within that race are the same and have the same qualities. These “preferences” may conceal internalized stereotypes about certain groups.
resources.author: jaygee

resources.title:
We’re so lucky [[that]] [[kind]] [[of]] [[thing]] [[doesn’t]] [[happen]] 
[[here]].
resources.definition: This comment is a form of microinvalidation and is often made by individuals in reference to learning about a tragic event that happened in another country or an instance of discrimination that has happened to an individual. Not only is this statement insensitive to the individuals harmed, it implies that this “could never happen here” when it could and potentially already has. It invalidates people’s experiences and, when used to speak about other countries, can perpetuate negative stereotypes.
resources.author: aspakowski

resources.title: LGBTQ... ((whatever)).
resources.definition: This statement is dismissive and offensive. It implies that learning the definition of the acronym is too much work or that it isn’t important. Not making an effort to fully understand communicates a tokenized effort at inclusion as opposed to a genuine effort to understand how to represent and include the community.
resources.author: aspakowski

resources.title: I’m so tanned. [[I]] [[am]] [[as]] [[dark]] [[as]] [[you]]!
resources.definition: This microaggression is harmful because it trivializes the often racist experiences of dark skinned people existing in society. Tanning, as a non-racialized person, does not equate to being dark/brown-skinned, as non-racialiazed people will never experience the same systemic discrimination, racism, and/or colourism that racialized and Black people face.
resources.author: tashshep

resources.title: That’s your personal preference.***
resources.definition: This statement is often said in reply to people who say that efforts for diversity, equity, and inclusion are a personal preference (e.g. assuming that ensuring accessibility is a personal preference)

resources.title: __Assuming__ __a__ __woman__ __customer__ __knows__ __nothing__ about cars, computers, home renos, etc.
resources.definition: This behaviour reinforces gender stereotypes related to masculinity and femininity and the hobbies and knowledge associated with each. It assumes that women are not experts or knowledgeable in these areas, or have done their research on these areas prior, and this assumption reinforces gender norms, stereotypes, and expectations of the hobbies and knowledge women have and ought to possess.
resources.author: indigo

resources.title: Assuming an older person’s lack of speed/ dexterity indicates cognitive decline.***
resources.definition: This microaggression manifests in many ways like using “baby talk” with older people and taking control of tasks being performed by an older person. It is diminishing and invalidating and can reinforce stereotypes related to the capabilities of older people.

resources.title: __How__ __can__ __you__ __be__ __sure__ __you’re__ __a__ __lesbian__ if you haven’t tried it with a man?
resources.definition: This question discredits one’s sexuality and implies that heterosexual relationships are inherently normal. A reverse question is hardly ever asked of heterosexual individuals and how they knew they were straight if they have never engaged in a relationship with someone of the same sex.
resources.author: annabrent

resources.title: They’re such a Jew!***
resources.definition: This phrase is used to describe stereotypical characteristics that individuals perceive are inherently linked to Jewish individuals. This perpetuates stereotypes and discrimination against Jewish individuals.
resources.author: kitedancer

resources.title: Are you 2SLGBTQ+?***
resources.definition: This question can suggest someone is only defined by a label. There are many identities that form part of the acronym, however people are still individuals with unique identities. Moreover, one does not need to know if someone else belongs to the 2SLGBTQ+ community. Asking such a question is prying for personal information when it might not be appropriate.
resources.author: wesmanlv

resources.title: I know what you mean.***
resources.definition: This statement typically occurs when someone is sharing an experience of discrimination, racism, sexism, ageism, homophobia, or others, and the listener claims to understand by making a link to a different situation that doesn’t involve discrimination, or the listener is not of the same identity as the individual sharing the story. This response undermines and invalidates the experience of discrimination.

resources.title: She’s always complaining (needy). She’s so shrill.***
resources.definition: These types of comments about women being shrill and emotional serve to monitor and dictate the emotions and tones of women and perpetuate stereotypes and expectations linked to the way women express themselves. They serve to downplay women’s ambitions, passions, and perspectives, and overall diminish the contributions of women.

resources.title: Assuming Muslim women are oppressed.***
resources.definition: This statement is based on assumptions and generalizations of religion and culture as it relates to Islam and gender. It perpetuates discrimination against Muslim people and women and is often used to demonize Muslim individuals and Islam as a whole.

resources.title: Believing all Muslim women wear a hijab.***
resources.definition: This belief shows a lack of understanding of the Muslim faith and perpetuates generalizations about the faith. There are intersectionalities in Islam - not all Muslim women wear the hijab. Some choose not to wear it. Assuming that everyone who is Muslim acts and dresses the same ignores differences within the religion and serves to perpetuate stereotypes.

resources.title: Is it a Green Card marriage?***
resources.definition: This comment suggests that two individuals in a relationship from different countries have dishonest intentions, and can be used to discriminate or make rude comments to individuals from other countries.
resources.author: jax

resources.title: What did you look like before you transitioned?***
resources.definition: This type of question about someone’s previous identity is intrusive and offensive. A transgender individual should not be asked about their past identity as it may be irrelevant to who they are now. Doing so can also bring up painful memories.
resources.author: mbcarradine

resources.title: Introducing/ referring to [[women]] [[by]] [[their]] [[first]] [[name]] while referring to [[men]] [[by]] [[their]] [[title]].
resources.definition: This introduction diminishes a woman’s accomplishments and achievements and puts them on an unequal footing in a group which can impact how others perceive them and their perspectives compared to men. It assumes that professionalism and masculinity are linked and undermines a woman’s accomplishments and perspectives.
resources.author: awkward_orchid

resources.title: Using the term __guys__ __for__ __entire__ __groups__.
resources.definition: This language (referring to groups of people overall, as “guys”) erases the experiences of those who identify as and experience life through the lens of other genders, and sets the default expectation to male. It is a form of non-inclusive language.

resources.title: Bisexual erasure***
resources.definition:
Bisexual erasure is when the existence and/or the legitimacy of bisexuality is questioned, trivialized, or denied. 
Bisexual people face unique experiences and challenges in the queer community. This erasure is socially harmful as it leads to the exclusion of bisexual people from the 2SLGBTQIA+ community. For example, bisexual people may not be represented in resources and supports, and their experiences are not always fully accepted. Examples of bisexual erasure may include assuming that someone in a relationship has “picked a side” or thinking that bisexuality is “just a phase”.

resources.title: I bet she slept her way to the top. ***
resources.definition:
This comment is derogatory and suggests that women can only be successful if they have exploitative sex, which grossly undermines their intelligence, abilities, and achievements. 

This statement also has the potential to cause psychological and emotional harm to those who are survivors of sexual harassment and violence, both in and outside of the workplace. 

This way of thinking sexualizes women, diminishes their accomplishments, and in cases of sexual violence or assault, deflects from the exploitation committed by perpetrators. This statement reinforces gender stereotypes and biases linked to womens’ abilities and their qualifications and can be used to discredit womens’ roles as leaders, or used to create barriers to women seeking and obtaining leadership roles.
resources.author: nicholab

resources.title: You're a scientist? Wow!***
resources.definition: This statement is a form of microinsult. Being surprised about someone’s expertise and/or specialization(s), whether intentional or unintentional, suggests that a person does not belong in the field and can invalidate one’s knowledge, skills, and capabilities. This microaggression is particularly present in fields that have a history of exclusion (e.g., STEM), where women and equity-deserving groups have, in many cases, experienced barriers to participation. Statements like this uphold common ways of thinking about what a scientist should look like, and what types of people can be scientists, and ultimately perpetuate biases.

resources.title: Calling a woman a ((girl)).
resources.definition:
Referring to an adult woman as a “girl” can be infantilizing and patronizing, and insinuates that women lack maturity and do not deserve proper recognition. 

While the word “girl” itself is not offensive, directing it at women gives the impression that they are not to be taken seriously. This microaggression can be more pronounced depending on the context, for example, if it is said in the workplace by someone who does not, in turn, call the men at work “boys”.

resources.title: You know the Jews; they stick together.***
resources.definition: This comment reinforces stereotypes claiming that Jewish people are disloyal and are only loyal to other Jewish people. It is used to demonize Jewish people, treat them as conniving, and reinforce stereotypes.
resources.author: croche

resources.title: Well you're ‘never’ here so [[we]] [[don’t]] [[have]] [[to]] [[tell]] [[you]] [[anything]].
resources.definition:
This microaggression on absenteeism and lateness relates to the broader stigmatization of the performance/productivity of those living with a disability. This idea of a lack of productivity among people with disabilities has been dispelled by research, particularly in environments where accommodations are provided. 

Absenteeism and lateness are often believed to be more common for those who live with disabilities, and this belief coupled with statements like “You're never here”, “You never come”, or “You never show up” reinforce biases and stereotypes about people with disabilities, and in the workplace can deny people with disabilities opportunities.

resources.title: Don’t you feel like __you’re__ __being__ __narrow__ __minded__?
resources.definition:
This microaggression contributes to stereotypes and biases about religion by assuming that following/practicing a given religion means one is ignorant, narrow-minded, or less free-thinking. This statement also assumes homogeneity within religious groups and can disenfranchise people based upon their religious beliefs. 

It suggests that every individual who believes in a specific religion holds the same beliefs and practices, denying the freedom of thought, belief, opinion and expression that exists within religious groups.
resources.author: dltyson

resources.title: I know you’re a different race but I can’t place it by your looks.***
resources.definition:
This question brings attention to one’s racial identity and attempts to delineate one’s proximity to whiteness. It is usually said in an effort to organize someone’s identity into neat categories of race, ethnicity, and/or nationality. While such “tidy” categories dominate popular thinking, they do not always reflect the realities of people’s identities and lived experience. 
This microaggression is similar to questions like “Where are you from?” and can undermine the nuances of one’s identity, imply that someone is not “from here” or is an “outsider” and can harm one's sense of belonging.
resources.author: dltyson

resources.title: You don’t look/act like you date Black guys/ girls/ people.***
resources.definition:
This comment suggests that someone has to look and/or act a certain way to date someone who is Black. It reproduces harmful racial stereotypes about Black individuals, and contributes to racial fetishization, and negatively shapes romantic and/or platonic relationships. 

Additionally, it invalidates sexual and romantic desire/attraction that exists across races, genders, sexualities, and other aspects of identity.
resources.author: areed

resources.title: Just be positive.***
resources.definition:
This common phrase contributes to toxic positivity, and can be socially, emotionally, and/or psychologically harmful. While it is helpful in many contexts to be positive and “see the bright side”, it ignores structural and systemic barriers, as well as bias and stereotypes, that negatively contribute to many people’s lives. Statements like “just be positive”, when said to an individual who has experienced discrimination, are akin to statements like “just get over it” and are forms of microinvalidations, which serve to invalidate and erase people’s experiences. This may lead the person to feel they are unable to talk about their feelings and experiences openly and stifle their ability to get the help and reassurance they may need. 

When said to someone living with a disability or someone living with mental health issues, for example, it can dismiss their feelings and lived realities, can harm their own personal perspective and intuition on their own mental health, and undermine their personal agency. Also, it may make someone feel like they are being pessimistic or negative, when they are really responding naturally and authentically.
resources.author: donna

resources.title: You don’t look Mexican.***
resources.definition:
This statement invalidates a person’s experience as a Latin American person and serves to uphold stereotypes and perceptions of what people should look like, act like, dress like, etc.

It also erases the vast history and diversity of different people that make up the community.
resources.author: marlagomezve

resources.title: She’s probably on her period.***
resources.definition: This statement is often said to women expressing an opinion and is similar to statements like “she is so shrill” or “she is so bossy”. This phrase invalidates and demeans a woman’s expressions of emotion and/or feelings and assumes that women have a lack of emotional control. This statement and statements of a similar nature are often said to women when expressing an assertive opinion. Statements like this, as well as other infantilizing statements, can be used to disregard women's contributions and deny women of leadership roles.

resources.title: You’re so ((resilient)).
resources.definition:
The statement “you're so resilient” and similarly “you're so brave” are often meant as compliments or statements of empowerment. Sometimes they are said to individuals sharing their experiences of discrimination and oppression, while other times they are said to individuals for simply existing. Examples include telling a person living with a disability how brave they are, or telling an individual who is transgender how resilient they are. 

Comments like these are harmful for several reasons. First, these statements imply that one’s identity is something to be resilient of. They suggest that it is inherently difficult to have a particular identity, or that a particular identity is abnormal, and then praise an individual for their bravery and resilience in spite of their identity. Additionally, when said to individuals expressing experiences of discrimination, statements like these contribute to “toxic positivity” and sometimes implies that people may be able to overcome oppression if they are simply resilient. This statement also may compel people to explain their experience with oppression to meet a narrative that centres “resiliency” and “bravery”.
resources.author: travisw

resources.title: That’s so lame.***
resources.definition: This expression is a form of ableist language. It has been used when referring to people living with disabilities and has harmful undertones related to weakness and incapability. Using the word and its associated expressions can be insensitive and ableist, as it reproduces negative stereotypes about people with disabilities.

resources.title: Your food is so __exotic/__ __disgusting/__ __weird__.
resources.definition: These descriptions are insensitive to the vast diversity of foods across the world and have racist and xenophobic undertones. Food that is “uncommon” or “exotic” to one person may be typical for someone else. Calling food “exotic”, “foreign”, or “uncommon” is to suggest that it is not normal and to uphold certain cultures and their foods as normal and dominant. Further, statements like these are homogenizing, implying that all people from certain racial, ethnic, and cultural groups all eat a specific food.

resources.title: [[Were]] [[you]] [[even]] [[born]] when [this or that] happened?
resources.definition:
When comments like this are used in reference to specific historical events in the attempt to discredit the views, ideas, and experiences of young people, it can imply that young people are uneducated and/or unaffected by such events. It implies that although someone is young, they don’t have experience or are not as cultured and therefore have less value than someone who is older.

Further, it fails to recognize the impacts of intergenerational trauma, where people may have connections to events that they may have not experienced directly. This is not always the case - for example, a young Indigenous person may have not directly experienced the horrors of the Canadian residential school system, but could have witnessed the lasting impacts of this cultural genocide on their families, communities, and other aspects of social life.

resources.title: Assuming bisexuality or pansexuality is [[“just]] [[a]] [[phase”]].
resources.definition:
Assuming that attraction to more than one gender will just pass over time is harmful and stigmatizing. This can include bisexual, pansexual, omnisexual, polysexual, and more identities. Assuming that bi+ spectrum identities are a phase is part of the larger issue of bisexual erasure or invisibility. Bisexual erasure is when the existence and/or the legitimacy of 
bi+ spectrum identities are questioned, trivialized, or denied. This has impacts on individuals, who can feel excluded and misunderstood. Further, this type of exclusion/erasure is sometimes known as monosexism (the assumption of only being attracted to one gender) also has societal, economic, and health impacts, as it leads to a lack of resources and supports for bisexual individuals.
